I love this particular quote from @GreatDismal so much that I used it as a chapter for my book on facial recognition (coming out later this year.) But I wanted to verify he actually said it, a question raised in Semafor's media newsletter. So I found myself listening to an NPR episode first aired in 1999. https://www.npr.org/2018/10/22/1067220/the-science-in-science-fiction
William Gibson, at 11:20: "As I've said many times, the future is already here, it's just not very evenly distributed."
Via Quote Investigator: https://quoteinvestigator.com/2012/01/24/future-has-arrived/

title: Bitwarden design flaw: Server side iterations

last_post.content:
People have been asking me about #Bitwarden ever since #LastPass has been breached. While I never took an in-depth look, I now at least evaluated the claims regarding their encryption:

https://palant.info/2023/01/23/bitwarden-design-flaw-server-side-iterations/

While the password manager being completely open-source with the option to self-host is great, otherwise I’m not too impressed. The issues in particular:

· Server-side iterations mechanism does not provide any security value. They should have known about it at least since 2020 when @dchest wrote about it, probably even since 2018 when I discussed the same flaw in LastPass. Yet they are still using it for their PR claims.
· 100,000 PBKDF2 iterations on the client side is too low, with the current OWASP recommendation being 310,000. They updated this setting (hopefully upgrading existing accounts as well) in 2018 seemingly to match LastPass and failed to adjust ever since.
· Bitwarden allows users to configure 5,000 iterations without even warning them. Not only is this value dangerously low, supporting it also allows a compromised production server to ask the client for a password hashed with 5,000 iterations – regardless of the actual setting.
· Bitwarden users have been pointing out the key derivation parameters being inadequate since at least 2018. Development of Argon2 support only started two weeks ago, and it isn’t coming from the core developers.

On the bright side, vault data is completely encrypted. No unencrypted URLs and such.

@bitwarden

title: Run Pandas on 1TB+ Directly in Your Data Warehouse

last_post.content:
Data science meets data warehouse!

The team at ponder.io has just launched its product that allows pandas code to run directly in a Snowflake data warehouse. This is the team that built Modin -- the pandas API, except scalable. This latest offering includes new capabilities to push data science computational work through the SQL interface, so that it executes in the DBMS. No data leaves home!

https://ponder.io/run-pandas-on-1tb-directly-in-your-data-warehouse/

title: Upper bound on the packing density of regular tetrahedra and octahedra

last_post.content:
Here's the proof that no packing of equal-sized regular tetrahedra can have density more than 1−2.4⋅10⁻²⁵:

https://arxiv.org/abs/1008.2830

I hope someone improves this upper bound! I'll bet the true upper bound is ~0.8563. I'd be shocked but delighted if someone can beat this.

(3/n, n = 3)

A call for revolutionizing PhD training: the needs of students are changing, but most institutions aren't adapting 👩‍🎓

PhD enrolment is rising, and a growing % are opting out of academia. Yet programs don't prepare them for other careers. Higher student-to-professor ratios also reduce the quality of supervision, and many have to endure poverty wages for years despite being the engines of their labs.

via https://doi.org/10.1038/d41586-023-00084-3

title: Peer Community In - free peer review & validation of preprints of articles

last_post.content:
Non-profit journals as a solution to open science?

Publishers charge researchers incredible amounts to remove paywalls from their own papers...and make unbelievable profits from doing so. Several have an >30% profit margin.

Initiatives such as @PeerCommunityIn provide an alternative: open access, non-profit journals that are free to publish in.

https://peercommunityin.org/
https://peercommunityjournal.org/

title: Cautionary Tales – The Myth of the Million Dollar Tulip Bulb

last_post.content:
Cautionary Tales – The Myth of the Million Dollar Tulip Bulb

RECORDED BEFORE AN AUDIENCE AT THE BRISTOL FESTIVAL OF ECONOMICS (17 November 2022)
The Dutch went so potty over tulip bulbs in the 1600s that many were ruined when the inflated prices they were paying for the plants collapsed - that's the oft-repeated story later promoted by best-selling Scottish writer Charles Macka

https://timharford.com/2023/01/cautionary-tales-the-rise-and-fall-of-the-bubble-guru/

title: India invokes emergency laws to ban BBC Modi documentary

last_post.content:
"The Indian government has invoked emergency laws to block a BBC documentary examining the role of the prime minister, Narendra Modi, during riots in the western state of Gujarat in 2002....

"The BBC also uncovered memos showing that Modi’s conduct was criticised at the time by western diplomats and the British government, including in a government report which found that the riots had “all the hallmarks of an ethnic cleansing”. https://www.theguardian.com/world/2023/jan/23/india-emergency-laws-to-ban-bbc-narendra-modi-documentary

This report, Terrorist Use of End-to-End Encryption: Insights from a Year of Multi-Stakeholder Discussion, centres upon this very important fact:

"Encryption experts, digital rights advocates, and service providers agree that the systematic surveillance of encrypted content _is technically unfeasible_ unless the security and privacy of all users is to be compromised."

https://www.techagainstterrorism.org/2023/01/11/terrorist-use-of-end-to-end-encryption-insights-from-a-year-of-multi-stakeholder-discussion/

title: Access is not the same as accessibility: A framework for making research papers truly open – arXiv.org blog

last_post.content:
Very glad to see the #arxiv steps toward #accessibility (#a11y). These include "offering well-formatted #HTML, alongside #PDF and #TeX source."
https://blog.arxiv.org/2023/01/19/access-is-not-the-same-as-accessibility-a-framework-for-making-research-papers-truly-open/

PS: There are 𝘮𝘢𝘯𝘺 reasons to offer well-formatted HTML alongside PDF, or to stop publishing PDF-only. Accessibility is first, followed closely by making work friendly to mobile users, users with low bandwidth, and users who need to text-mine, cut/paste, or use machine translation.

There's a good discussion of packing regular tetrahedra here:

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tetrahedron_packing

and here:

Jeffrey Lagarias and Chuanming Zong, Mysteries in packing regular tetrahedra
http://www.ams.org/notices/201211/rtx121101540p.pdf

The proof that equal-sized regular tetrahedra can't fill 3d space boils down to thinking about the picture here, where θ is a bit more than 7°. But I'd hate to have to formalize it in a completely rigorous way, on a computer. (Some other people would enjoy that challenge.)

(2/n)

Aristotle claimed that identical regular tetrahedra could be packed in a way that fills space. It seems unlikely if you actually try it - but only in 1925 was it proved impossible. And only in 2010 did people prove a nontrivial upper bound on the density of the packing you can achieve, namely

0.9999999999999999999999974

On the other hand, the densest known packing has density about .8563 - there's a discussion and picture on Wolfram's website:

https://blog.wolfram.com/2010/08/30/tetrahedra-packing/

(1/n)

If you've been following #fediverse user counts, you've probably seen it is dropping from the Nov/Dec peaks. But have you noticed that simultaneously toots per month is climbing, fast?

That's a lot of tire kickers dropping out, but those who stick, are really active.

https://fediverse.observer/stats (end of page)

This is a really good paper:

https://www.arxiv-vanity.com/papers/2212.03551/

Gets at a thing that has long worried me: Experts in the field can use conversational shorthand like "believe" and "know" with little risk. Outsiders hear those terms and naturally anthropomorphize.

LLMs are powerful and useful, but require human oversight. Just because GPT-3 says it doesn't make it so. We need to explain in ways that highlights risk to ordinary folks.

Came my way via @simon.

title: Topological Phases in a PT-Symmetric Dissipative Kitaev Chain

last_post.content: Today's #arXivsummary: https://arxiv.org/abs/2301.08446 by Kawasaki & Obuse. Authors study the topological phase in the dissipative Kitaev chain via a Markovian quantum master equation. Lindbladians are classified in terms of non-Hermitian topological phases. Lindbladian retains PT symmetry. #CondMat #MesHall #arXiv_2301_08446

last_post.content:
"Yes, we are going to take away all the features you get with your digital media and sell them back to you one click at a time. So what?"

title: Tell Us About Your Experience With the Liver Transplant System

last_post.content:
Every year, thousands of Americans facing liver failure try to get new organs. Many of these are successful. But some experiences with the liver transplant process go wrong. The chances of success often depend on which hospital replaces your liver.

For an upcoming @ProPublica story, I'm looking to speak with medical providers, experts, regulators, and patients who have experience with our liver transplant system. If you're one of these people, please fill out this form. https://www.propublica.org/getinvolved/tell-us-about-your-experience-with-the-liver-transplant-system

L'avenir de la recherche d'information n'est pas dans les grands modèles de langage qui ont réponse à tout car trouver de l'information nécessite que celle-ci soit située pour répondre à la diversité des contextes d'usages : https://dl.acm.org/doi/abs/10.1145/3498366.3505816 "Nous devrions chercher à créer des outils qui aident les utilisateurs à trouver et à donner un sens aux informations plutôt que des outils qui prétendent tout faire pour eux." @emilymbender et Chirag Shah

But maybe we don't need to settle on Mastodon in advance, eg https://www.google.com/search?q=koo&tbm=nws&sxsrf=ALiCzsanHwKzGBO4v27Sq2TTCOHCwo_3jg:1668888717960&source=lnt&tbs=qdr:m&sa=X&ved=2ahUKEwjoldD5hrv7AhVXXvEDHfRyBAUQpwV6BAgEEBk&biw=1255&bih=729&dpr=2.5

I remember when Netscape announced that it was going to release the source code for its web browser. I'd been working in open source for decades, but this was the first major corporate contribution of previously-closed code to the community. It was huge. (I had, not long before, tried to get my employer Informix to open source the Illustra DBMS, but failed).

Jamie Zawinski was right in the middle of it all. He just posted this history on his blog. Fun reading!

https://www.jwz.org/blog/2023/01/mozilla-orgs-25th-anniversary/

title: Publishers lament the removal of Twitter Moments as referral traffic dips

last_post.content:
News publishers are bemoaning the drop in Twitter traffic referrals under Musk. But they have a plan: They'll put more of their stuff on Facebook and LinkedIn.

Because they're monumentally oblivious to the lesson they've (again) failed to learn. Namely: Do not trust or rely on centralized systems you don't control.

https://digiday.com/media/publishers-lament-the-removal-of-twitter-moments-as-referral-traffic-dips/

title: Inside the Moonshot Effort to Finally Figure Out the Brain

last_post.content:
The MICrONS program was a hugely ambitious effort to map the connectivity patterns of 1 mm3 of mouse cortex and their relationships to brain function. I know that it led to some tremendous technical advances in automated electron microscopy and processing of that data. It also led to a connectivity map for 200K neurons and 500 million synapses.

https://www.technologyreview.com/2017/10/12/148291/inside-the-moonshot-effort-to-finally-figure-out-the-brain/

What I understand less about is whether the new concepts and findings that emerged from the project.
@neurobongo, @xaq, (anyone): What is the status there? (Note this Q is not a criticism - if it's all still tech and maps thus far, that's still a really important step).

Very thoughtful analysis of #receptiogate by David Rundle: "#Receptiogate and gate-keeping", https://bonaelitterae.wordpress.com/2023/01/23/receptiogate-and-gate-keeping/. Among several good points, this final one: "...asserting status is not a route to acceptance as a scholar; on the contrary, it is symptomatic of the unscholarly". And another one from earlier in the piece: "...realising that Receptio’s fabrication is a parody of a system of higher education which is itself beyond parody."

title: Creating a simple lighthouse audit to detect a button

last_post.content:
The final post about training an ML model to detect Buttons.

I created a Lighthouse Audit that gets each of the links on a page and runs the visual representation of it through the ML model adding the results to a lighthouse report.

title: Self-Consistency Improves Chain of Thought Reasoning in Language Models

last_post.content:
I just noticed that Self-Consistency can substantially improve the performance even on the tasks where CoT works worse than the standard prompting. I wonder if the gain becomes insignficant if we use SFT or RLHF. If not, can we exploit this?

https://arxiv.org/abs/2203.11171

And another interesting paper analyzes effect of local labor demand shocks in Indonesia in a male-dominated industry (mining), finding that these shocks lead to local structural transformation effects that also affect women (who move out of agriculture)
https://drive.google.com/file/d/10g50Os2SfR1qVuzCWI5vXrNqWbtlKdMr/view

An RCT in Kenya joint w/ @carocastillag@twitter.com + Murphy analyzes an intervention targeting alcohol consumption + finds substantial effects on ⬇️ physical + sexual IPV - substance use is a huge challenge in many LMICs + often understudied by economists
https://drive.google.com/file/d/1C0vFZLGEoysH3emGy-O1chcevkBkx2bv/view

and ⬆️ utilization of formal care in areas w/more female doctors

We compare user interpretation of static vs. dynamic #movement displays in 2D. Our continuing work with MOVE Lab at UCSB is looking at the cognition of 2D vs. 3D displays! More to come. #dataviz
